content: The Act is known as the "Stopping Abuse and Fraud in Electronic Lending Act of 2018" or the "SAFE Lending Act of 2018". It focuses on consumer control over bank accounts. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to prohibit unauthorized remotely created checks, defining them as checks not created by the financial institution holding the customer account and lacking the account holder's signature. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to prohibit unauthorized remotely created checks, which are checks not created by the financial institution holding the customer account and lacking the account holder's signature. A remotely created check can only be issued by a person designated in writing by the consumer, with the consumer able to revoke this designation at any time. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to prohibit unauthorized remotely created checks issued in response to consumer rights under consumer financial protection laws. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act is amended to include protections for electronic fund transfers in credit extensions for small-dollar consumer credit transactions. SEC. 3. TRANSPARENCY AND CONSUMER EMPOWERMENT IN SMALL-DOLLAR LENDING. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a registration requirement for small-dollar lenders. The term 'small-dollar consumer credit transaction' refers to credit transactions not exceeding $5,000 or a higher amount set by the Bureau annually, payable in installments and not part of an open-end credit plan. The term 'small-dollar consumer credit transaction' refers to credit transactions not exceeding $5,000 or a higher amount set by the Bureau annually, payable in installments of less than 12 months or in an open-end credit plan. Registration with the Bureau is required before issuing credit in such transactions. The text discusses the compliance of small-dollar consumer credit transactions with state laws regarding rates, fees, and charges when conducted through various electronic means or by a national bank. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a new section after section 109. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a new section after section 109 regarding registration requirements for small-dollar lenders and prohibition on certain fees related to prepaid accounts. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new rules for prepaid accounts, such as declining transactions exceeding the account balance without charging a fee. The Bureau may also prohibit fees to prevent unfair practices and promote consumer understanding of costs. SEC. 140B of the Truth in Lending Act introduces restrictions on lead generation in small-dollar consumer credit transactions. In SEC. 140B of the Truth in Lending Act, definitions for terms like 'Internet access service', 'Internet information location tool', and 'sensitive personal financial information' are provided. It also defines 'small-dollar consumer credit transaction'. Any person involved in distributing sensitive personal financial information for small-dollar consumer credit transactions must prominently display identification information. The Truth in Lending Act defines terms related to small-dollar consumer credit transactions and requires disclosure of contact information for those involved in distributing sensitive personal financial information. Prohibition is placed on lead generation activities unless directly providing credit to consumers, with the Bureau retaining authority to further restrict covered activities. The provision of telecommunications, Internet access, or Internet information services is not considered facilitating the distribution of sensitive personal financial information in small-dollar consumer credit transactions. This exemption also applies to activities such as transmission, storage, retrieval, hosting, and formatting of communications without altering the content, except for deletion consistent with the Communications Act of 1934. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a technical and conforming amendment. SEC. 5. STUDIES. In this section, definitions are provided for "appropriate committees of Congress" and "Indian tribe." The Comptroller General of the United States is required to conduct a study on the availability of capital on reservations of Indian tribes within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to conduct a study on the availability of capital on Indian reservations and the impact of small-dollar consumer credit on economic opportunity for members of Indian tribes. Consultation with various entities, including the Bureau of Indian Affairs and federally recognized tribes, is mandated. The study results will be submitted to Congress. The United States must submit the study to Congress as required. The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection must adopt final rules within 1 year of this Act's enactment to implement its provisions and amendments.
